publicationStmt.p: This project encoded newspaper and periodical articles on ghost hoaxes in the Victorian period. This publication of the text serves as data in a collaborative laboratory edition for the 2022 NEH Institute "Advanced digital editing: modeling the text and making the edition" at the University of Pittsburgh.

seriesStmt.title: Ghost hoaxes in 19th-century British news media

sourceDesc.p: All texts in this collection were sourced from British periodical and newspaper archives, transcribed,and encoded. The citation below was provided by the archive and appears exactly as given.

p.bibl: "The Ghost." Penny Satirist, 27 Jan. 1838, p. 2. 19th Century UK Periodicals, https://tinyurl.com/yejmuju9. Accessed 21 June 2022.

projectDesc.p: This document is part of a larger digital collection of stories of ghost hoaxes from the 18th and 19th century London newspapers and periodicals. The project explores the beginnings of mass print media in a metropolitan area at a time when technology and education made reading increasingly common and inexpensive.

The corpus holds 36 individual documents, which reflect a diverse mix of reporting on various hauntings in and around London between 1804 and 1889. The PDF and JPEGs from online databases were transcribed using ABBYFineReader OCR, then corrected and occasionally manually transcribed if document quality necessitated it. After normalization in plain text, all documents were upconverted to TEI XML.

normalization.p: Earlier texts have had some spelling normalization due to errors in OCR. Typographic em dashes are longer than modern em dashes, so all dashes have been normalized to modern em dash length.

quotation.p: All extraneous white space used by printers to avoid overlapping with letters has been removed. All quotes are simply tagged with the q tag.

body.p: The canny Scot has been wilily hunting the canny ghost for several days. The zeal of our friend, which was somewhat cool at first, and animated alone by his patriotism, or public spirit, which is at all times but a niggardly paymaster, was increased as he proceeded by the interesting particulars which he learned by the way concerning this man of the mist. At Peckham, a young woman came running along, as if for life, and threw herself into Macdougal's arms, screaming for protection. It was with the greatest difficulty he could get rid of her. It was only by proposing to rouse a Justice of the Peace, and give information of the spring-heeled visitor's arrival, that the girl, whose delicacy prevented her from appearing in such a public capacity, silently withdrew, and Sandy was left alone to brave the pricipalities and the powers of the spiritual world.

After this, he went out of the highway a little, to see if Chance would direct him to the monster against which he had previously well secured himself, by putting a horse shoe into his pocket, and eating an adder boiled in ewe's milk, and there he really did see a fearful image coming right up to him. There were two huge eyes gleaming fire and flame about the middle of its body, and a man's head above, strongly illuminated, and sending forth a glare of light for many yards around it. Sandy held the horse shoe fast in his left hand, and rubbed his knees with the other as he proceeded. Honour alone gave him resolution to go on, for he declares he had very little faith in the horseshoe. At last the monster approached him, Avaunt thee, wraith, said Sandy, horror-struck, and giving way to let the deserter from the tomb have a free passage. The monster replied, fine evening, in a very mild tone. Sandy resumed courage immediately, and looking up, saw a donkey with a lantern fixed to each side of its head, and a stout, happy looking country lass sitting on its back, with a lantern in one hand, and a basket in the other. Fine evening, said Sandy, whose heart was immediately disburdened. But afraid to proceed any further, he turned round, and proceeded towards the highway with the ass and its fair pilot, who, however, seemed not to relish his company, for his sudden change of resolution seemed somewhat suspicious. Just, then, an inspector of police rode up. The girl stopped and spoke to him, and Sandy walked on. He was soon overtaken by the police officer, who asked him where he had been, and whither he was going. Sandy did not well know what to say. He was therefore suspected, taken to the station-house, and when he ingeniously told his examiners that he had come from London upon a mission to lay the ghost, he raised a roar of laughter, but by no means tended to lay the suspicions of the blues. He was kept in the station-house all night, and came home in a deuce of a plight the next morning.

Not deterred, however, by this unfortunate termination to his first adventure, he determined to make another attempt, and the Major himself proposed, for friendship and a lark, to accompany him. The Major is an opium eater on important occasions, and before he set out he administered to himself an unusual dose, and persuaded Sandy to join him in the prescription. They proceeded towards Kensington Gardens, and their courage mounted as they went. Their very eyes emitted rays of light, and their two sticks, which they wielded with extraordinary vigour, so alarmed the minds of all they met, that there can be no doubt that they were taken for the ghost itself, but their good fortune, and the fears of the spectators, prevented them from being apprehended. Being fatigued at last, they sat down on a seat in the garden, and the Major fell fast asleep. Sandy was half dozing himself, but being afraid of the cold, resolved to rouse the Major, and move; but just as he was about to stir, he heard a voice in the tree above, which at once electrified him, and compelled him to listen to the following song, part of which he has forgotten, and part is made up from a partial recollection:—

lg.l: If they lay me I'll go back;
Meanwhile around the town I'll jump
White, and green, and flaming blue,
Fling your feet around your head,
Some say I am a Marquis,
And they lay their bets I'll soon be duck'd:
But they never lay the ghost.
But others swear my step's too light,
To see if people's minds have yet
Ah, ah! its funny now to see
The fellow swore I was a hoax,
And that he would me seize;
I peeped in his face when strolling home,
And left him on his knees.
To take me to the station,
Mary, come up, says I, and he
They set a watch-dog on me, too,
The watch-dog growled, and barked, and ran,
It's pleasing to see how safely still
A ghost can walk the stage.
For I see that spite of gas and steam,
The ghostly fathers of the church
For truth without is stale as beer,
That in the light has been.
Destroying night, they've spoiled the rest
They'll never let their servants take
For fearing this, and dreading that,

body.p: The spell was on Sandy as long as the song continued, and looking up he saw a huge green figure, very luminous and transparent, dancing Jim Crow on a large branch of the tree; how to proceed he knew not, he had never studied magic, and could not draw the ring nor repeat the incantation, he had forgotten to settle these necessary preliminaries before he set out; he therefore determined to reserve the laying to another opportunity; accordingly, he roused the Major, who was snoring loud, and would, most probably, have snored himself at last out of time and space if he had not been thus forcibly dragged from the brink of eternity—Sandy whispered in his ears, there it is, and pointed to the tree; the Major hurriedly pulled out a pistol and fired right up, but the ghost swallowed up both the flash and the smoke, and the bullet whizzed right through its under jaw, and cerebellum, without doing it a bit of mischief. They therefore solemnly concluded, that nothing but an adjuration in due form with all the enchantments of frankincence and tripod, pentacle, chrystal and ring, would prove effectual.

As this will be attended with considerable expence, it is proposed to institute a subscription for the purpose, which we have no doubt the piety, and the public spirit, and the patriotism of our readers, will meet with a ready and a cordial reply. Subscribers' names will be regularly published. Those who subscribe one sovereign and upwards, will have their names in capitals. Five shillings and upwards, in Long Primer. One shilling, etc., in Brevier; and pence in Nonpareil. Subscriptions will be received by all agents and venders of the Penny Satirist in town and country.
